item.title: Implementing a Simple Caesar Cipher in Haskell
item.description:
Introduction

Today, we’re going to implement a simple Caesar cipher in Haskell. A Caesar cipher is a type of substitution cipher where each letter in the plaintext is replaced by a letter some fixed number of positions down the alphabet. For example, with a shift of 3, ‘A’ would be replaced by ‘D’, ‘B’ would become ‘E’, and so on. This exercise will help you understand basic Haskell syntax, data types, and function definitions.

item.title: Implementing a Simple Calculator in Python
item.description:
Introduction

Today, we’re going to build a simple calculator in Python. This calculator will take two numbers and an operator as input from the user, perform the corresponding arithmetic operation, and display the result. This exercise will help you solidify your understanding of input/output, basic arithmetic operations, and conditional statements in Python.

  1. Taking User Input: We need to receive numbers and the operation from the user. We’ll use the input() function to achieve this. Because input() returns a string, we’ll need to convert the numerical inputs to the appropriate data type (float or int).
  2. Performing Arithmetic Operations: We’ll need to handle the four basic arithmetic operations: addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. We’ll use the standard +, -, *, and / operators.

item.title: Building a Simple URL Shortener in Elixir
item.description:
Introduction

Today, we’re going to build a very simple URL shortener in Elixir. Imagine you have a really long URL, something like https://www.example.com/very/long/path/with/lots/of/parameters?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=promotion. We want to create a shorter, more manageable URL that redirects to this original one. We’ll focus on the core logic of generating a short code and associating it with the long URL, without delving into database persistence or web frameworks.

Explanation

item.title: Implementing a Simple Palindrome Checker in Kotlin
item.description:
Introduction

Today, we are going to implement a simple palindrome checker in Kotlin. A palindrome is a word, phrase, number, or other sequence of characters which reads the same backward or forward. Our goal is to write a function that can determine whether a given string is a palindrome, ignoring case and non-alphanumeric characters.

Explanation

The challenge of building a palindrome checker involves several considerations:

  1. Case Sensitivity: Palindromes should be case-insensitive. “Racecar” is a palindrome, and so is “racecar”. We need to convert the input string to either lowercase or uppercase.
  2. Non-Alphanumeric Characters: Spaces, punctuation, and other non-alphanumeric characters should be ignored. “A man, a plan, a canal: Panama” is a palindrome if these characters are removed. We’ll need to filter these out.
  3. String Reversal: We need an efficient way to compare the original string (after cleaning) with its reversed version.

item.title: Implementing a Simple Stack in Haskell
item.description:
Introduction

Today, we are going to implement a simple stack data structure in Haskell. A stack is a fundamental data structure that follows the Last-In-First-Out (LIFO) principle. This means the last element added to the stack is the first one to be removed. We will implement push, pop, and peek operations to interact with our stack.

Explanation

The main challenge in implementing a stack in Haskell lies in its immutability. We cannot directly modify the stack in place. Instead, each operation will return a new stack.

Explanation

  3. Count the Words: Store and update the count of each word. We can use a dictionary to achieve this, where the word is the key and the count is the value.
  4. Handle Edge Cases: Consider how to deal with empty input strings or strings with only punctuation.
